name: Integrate Tines with PhishER
title: Integrate Tines with PhishER
body:
You can use webhooks to integrate your Tines platform with PhishER. The Tines platform allows you to connect to a REST API or web application and automate your workflows.

With this integration, you can use webhooks to send information from your PhishER console to your Tines platform. For example, you can configure webhooks to notify your Tines platform when a user reports an email using the Phish Alert Button (PAB). You can also configure webhooks to send automatic notifications from a SOAR platform to a communication tool, such as Slack. By using this integration, you can simplify workflows and save time for your organization. For general information about using webhooks in PhishER, visit our Create and Manage Webhooks in Your PhishER Platform article.

Creating Webhooks in Your PhishER Platform

Before you can set up this integration, you'll need to create a webhook in your PhishER console. To create a webhook, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your PhishER console.
  2. Navigate to Settings > Webhook.
  3. Click the New Webhook button in the top-right corner of the page to open the Add Webhook Settings page.
  4. Fill out the fields on the Add Webhook Settings page. For more information about our recommended settings, see the screenshot and list below:
    1. Name: In this field, enter a meaningful name for your webhook. This name will help your admins recognize the purpose of the webhook.
    2. URL: In this field, enter the callback URL for your webhook.
      Note: If you want to rewrite or shorten the URL, we recommend using one of our compatible rewriters or shorteners. For a list of compatible options, visit our FAQ: PhishER article.
    3. Authorization: From this drop-down menu, select one of the following protocols: No Auth, API Key, Bearer Token, or Basic Auth. We recommend keeping the default setting, which is No Auth.
    4. Available Data: Select one or more types of data that you would like to send to the webhook. We recommend that you select the Raw, Links, Tags, PhishML, and Attachments check boxes.
    5. (Optional) Custom Data: If you want to add custom data to your webhook’s payload, click the plus sign icon. Then, fill out the key and value fields.
    6. (Optional) Custom Headers: If you want to add a custom header, click the plus sign icon. Then, fill out the key and value fields.
    7. Message Tags: We recommend that you select the Success and Failure check boxes if you would like PhishER to assign a tag when the webhook is used to send data. Enter "WEBHOOK_SUCCESS" in the field next to the Success check box. Then, enter "WEBHOOK_FAILURE" in the field next to the Failure check box.
  5. Click Create.

After you create the webhook, you can create a PhishER action and select the Send to Webhook option. This option allows PhishER to send the reported messages that are affected by that action to your organization’s webhook.

Connecting to Your Tines Platform

Once you have created a webhook in PhishER, you will need to create an external workflow for the webhook. The steps for creating a workflow will vary depending on the action you want to perform, such as connecting PhishER to Slack using Tines. Example steps for connecting PhishER to Slack are listed below.

  1. Create an ingestion point to parse the Webhook payload.
  2. Unpack the EML contents from the presigned S3 URL.
  3. Run intelligence on email domains, IP addresses, and links. You can use third party and internal threat intel to run the intelligence.
  4. Navigate to your Slack workspace and build a custom Slack app using the manifest file template below.
    Tip:You can click the image below to view a text file of the manifest text file in a new tab.

  1. Copy the Webhook URL from your Slack workspace to point to the Slack channel of your choice.

  1. Use Slack's Block Kit to create your Slack notification. For an example, see the screenshot below.
    Tip:You can click the image below to view a text file of the manifest text file in a new tab.

  1. Send the Intel to your Slack App via HTTPs POST Call.
  2. POST Slack Message and the message will be posted to the Slack channel.

Tines Story Example

You can use the .txt file below as a starting point to connecting PhishER to your Tines platform. Once you access the manifest file by clicking the image, you can import the story to the Tines group of your choosing.

Tip:You can click the image below to view a text file of the manifest text file in a new tab.

For further assistance with this integration, contact our support team.

images.alt:
The image displays the **"Add Webhook Settings"** configuration form, utilized for defining a new system integration webhook endpoint.

**Primary Input Fields:**
*   **Name:** Standard text input field for webhook identification.
*   **URL:** Text input field for the destination URI, with the hint text: "Enter a valid URL for this webhook."
*   **Authorization:** Dropdown menu for defining authentication schema, currently set to **"No Auth."**

**Available Data (d):**
This section features a two-column list of data fields available for inclusion in the webhook payload. Enabled (checked) fields are: **Raw, Tags, PhishML,** and **Attachments.** Other available options include Body (HTML/Text), Links, Headers, Message History, VirusTotal, and Message ID.

**Custom Fields (e, f):**
*   **Custom Data:** Input section allowing the addition of custom data fields. Features a **[+]** button to initiate field creation.
*   **Custom Headers:** Input section for defining custom HTTP headers. Features a **[+]** button to initiate header creation.

**Message Tags (g):**
This section defines the associated system tags for operational status:
*   **Success:** Checkbox enabled. Associated editable text field contains **WEBHOOK\_SUCCESS**.
*   **Failure:** Checkbox enabled. Associated editable text field contains **WEBHOOK\_FAILURE**.

The form submission is controlled by the primary Call to Action (CTA) button, **"Create,"** located at the bottom of the interface.

images.alt:
This image displays a seven-line snippet of a structured configuration file, potentially YAML or similar declarative data format, within a dark-themed text editor environment.

**UI Elements and Context:**
*   Line numbers 1 through 7 are visible along the left margin.
*   The background color is dark teal, and the text is rendered in light gray/white, consistent with a dark mode code editor.
*   Data is organized hierarchically using colons (`:`) and indentation.

**Text and Data Structure (Key-Value Pairs):**
1.  `_metadata:` (Top-level configuration key)
2.  `major_version: 1`
3.  `minor_version: 1`
4.  `display_information:` (Nested key structure)
5.  `name: APP_NAME` (Placeholder string value)
6.  `description: DESCRIPTION` (Placeholder string value)
7.  `background_color: "#000000"` (Hexadecimal string value defining black)

The section defines metadata, including versioning (1.1) and display settings for an application, utilizing placeholder text for the name and description fields.
images.context: to view a text file of the manifest text file in a new tab.

images.alt:
This image depicts a section of an application configuration interface, specifically focused on integrating webhooks.

**UI Structure and Navigation:**
The screen utilizes a two-column layout. The left column serves as a persistent navigation pane, organized under two main headings: **Settings** and **Features**. The currently active configuration page is highlighted in blue under the "Features" heading: **Incoming Webhooks**. Other visible navigation items include: Basic Information, Collaborators, Socket Mode, Install App, App Manifest (labeled **BETA**), Manage Distribution, App Home, Org Level Apps, Interactivity & Shortcuts, and Slash Commands.

**Main Content Area:**
The right column displays the content for the selected feature.
*   **Page Header:** Incoming Webhooks (H1 title).
*   **Content Section Title:** Activate Incoming Webhooks (H2 title).
*   **Descriptive Text:** The body text defines the feature: "Incoming webhooks are a simple way to post messages. They make use of normal HTTP requests with a JSON message and a few other optional details." The text also specifies that the feature requires a bot user and explains that a new Webhook URL is generated upon each app installation. A partially visible blue banner across the top states: "We've built an easier way to make all your changes."
images.context: rong> from your Slack workspace to point to the Slack channel of your choice.

images.alt:
This image depicts a section of a user interface dedicated to configuration settings, structured into two columns identified by bold headings and separated by a horizontal rule.

**UI Elements and Text:**

1.  **Column 1 (Webhook URL):**
    *   **Heading:** `Webhook URL`
    *   **Data Field:** A read-only text field displaying a truncated, grey-text URL starting with `https://hooks.slack.com/servic...`.
    *   **Action Button:** A button labeled **Copy** (highlighted by a red bounding box annotation) is positioned immediately to the right of the URL data field, allowing users to transfer the URL to the clipboard.

2.  **Column 2 (Channel):**
    *   **Heading:** `Channel`
    *   **Data Value:** Plain text indicating the destination, reading `A private channel`.

**Context:** The interface segment is documenting the configuration output for a registered Slack webhook integration, showing the integration endpoint and its designated destination channel.

The image displays a snippet of code in a technical text editor interface, utilizing a dark theme (dark teal background with light, monospaced font). The content is structured as a JSON object, likely representing a notification or message payload.

**UI Elements:**
*   Line numbers are visible on the left margin, ranging from 1 to 12.
*   Syntax highlighting is present, differentiating keys (e.g., `"payload"`, `"type"`) from string values (e.g., `"Hello"`, `"header"`) and structural elements.

**Code Structure and Content (JSON):**

*   **Line 1:** `{` (Object start)
*   **Line 2:** `"payload": {` (Key-value pair defining the primary object content)
*   **Line 3:** `"text": "Hello",` (String value)
*   **Line 4:** `"blocks": [` (Array start, likely for structured message formatting)
*   **Line 5:** `{` (Block object start)
*   **Line 6:** `"type": "header",` (Defines the block as a header element)
*   **Line 7:** `"text": {` (Nested object defining the header text properties)
*   **Line 8:** `"type": "plain_text",` (Specifies the text format)
*   **Line 9:** `"text": "PhishER Alert – New Phishing Email Spotted!",` (The specific content of the alert header)
*   **Line 10:** `"emoji": "true"` (Boolean value represented as a string, likely enabling emoji support)
*   **Line 11:** `}` (Text object end)
*   **Line 12:** `},` (Block object end, followed by a comma indicating further content is truncated)

**Context:** The content suggests a system alert mechanism, specifically a "PhishER Alert," designed to notify users about a new phishing email detection. The structure closely resembles formatting conventions used by messaging platforms (e.g., Slack's Block Kit) for constructing complex messages.
images.context: ow to view a text file of the manifest text file in a new tab.

images.alt:
This image displays a snippet of a configuration file, formatted in JSON, presented within a code editor environment utilizing dark theme syntax highlighting. The content defines an exported operational workflow or "Story," likely related to a cybersecurity or phishing response platform (indicated by "PhishER Story").

**UI Context:**
The screen displays code/data structure text against a dark teal background. Syntax highlighting differentiates data types: keys are white/light cyan, strings are dark yellow/green, numbers (`3`, `0`) are magenta/red, and reserved keywords/booleans (`null`, `false`) are orange/yellow.

**Data Structure (Top Level):**
The primary object contains the following key-value pairs:
1.  **"schema\_version":** `3` (Integer).
2.  **"name":** `"Example PhishER Story"` (String).
3.  **"description":** `null` (Null value).
4.  **"guid":** `"78149063d6294ce9ae08e18d707d1c97"` (String, top-level unique identifier).
5.  **"exported\_at":** `"2021-10-13T18:12:27Z"` (String, ISO 8601 timestamp).
6.  **"agents":** (Array of objects, defining active components).

**Nested Agent Configuration:**
The `agents` array contains at least one object, which defines a webhook agent:
1.  **"type":** `"Agents::WebhookAgent"` (String, defining the agent class).
2.  **"name":** `"Incoming PhishER Webhook"` (String, user-friendly name).
3.  **"disabled":** `false` (Boolean).
4.  **"guid":** `"ad58f01f5a33fc5f8be3171d1d927aa2"` (String, agent-specific unique identifier).
5.  **"options":** (Nested object containing configuration parameters):
    *   **"secret":** `"d4ea81823050bad4ab7666ec2986a7df"` (String, a 32-character hexadecimal secret key).
    *   **"verbs":** `"get,post"` (String, specifying allowed HTTP methods).
6.  **"keep\_events\_for":** `0` (Integer, retention setting).
